conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, and their size and position depend on the light source's position relative to the object and surface.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are currently cast on the ground by the objects above them.
Moving the light source forward changes the angle at which light rays hit the objects, affecting both the position and size of the shadows.
As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift backward because the light rays will come from a more forward position.
The size of the shadows will generally decrease as the light source moves forward due to the angle of the light rays becoming more perpendicular to the surface.
Shadow A will move backward and decrease in size.

When the light source moves forward above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will all move backward and decrease in size.
